intro.placeholder: Add notes on this lesson's topic and goals.

labWork.title: Activities

problems.title: Lesson 0.1 Using CLUE and Dataflow Programming

text: Overview:
In this activity, you will be introduced to CLUE, a collaborative learning platform that we will use throughout the neural engineering unit.
You will also be introduced to Dataflow, a visual computer programming interface that is part of the CLUE platform.
Learning Objectives:
After completing this activity, you will be able to add and share content on CLUE and make simple computer programs using Dataflow.
Welcome to CLUE!

In CLUE, everyone works in a group with up to four people. When you start an activity, CLUE drops you into a group randomly. You can change groups by clicking on the group number in the upper right corner. Then, you can either join an existing group that has fewer than four students, or start a new group. Your teacher may ask you to join a specific group. When you change groups, your work moves with you.

Groups are important in CLUE. You can learn from classmates in your group and they can learn from you. Many features of CLUE are designed to help you share information and learn from others in your group and in your class.
Each lesson in CLUE has three parts. The tabs above display each part:

• Introduction
  • Activities
  • Reflection
Please click on the "Activities" tab to continue.

On the right is your workspace. You can arrange the screen to show My Resources or My Workspace or to have the screen split. Hover over the three vertical dots on the divider between your Resources and your Workspace and click the arrows to change the screen. You can also close the Resources view by clicking the “X” on the upper right corner of the Resources panel.
To edit your workspace, you must first add a tile. You get a tile in your workspace by either

• Dragging a tile from My Resources (left side) in CLUE into My Workspace (right side)
  • Dragging a new tile from the menu on the left of your workspace
  • Click a button on the menu to add a new tile to the bottom of your workspace

All tiles have a waffle (gray box with six dots) in the upper right corner if you hover over it. To drag the tile, click the waffle and hold it down as you drag it to your workspace. As you drag the tile into the workspace, a blue line shows where the tile will go when you let go.

Tip: When your working session is over, just close the browser window. Your workspace is saved automatically (there is no Save button) If you are on a shared computer, be sure to log out of learn.concord.org.
OK, get ready... Here we go!
Introduction to tile types
Try to make a text tile in your Workspace on the right (press the menu button with the letter A on it). Write down some things you hope to learn in this Neural Engineering unit.
Tip: by hovering your mouse over the tile menu you will see the function of each tile.
Now insert an image into your workspace. You can upload using the button or you can drag images from your desktop. Describe in your workspace how you might use images to document your work.
Next, try to make a table. Fill the table in with some numbers, and change the column header names to something you might use in this class. Describe the meaning of your data in text.
Introduction to Dataflow

Because these lessons involve engineering and robotics, you will also need a programming tool that can read sensor data and control outputs. In this unit, the programming tool is called Dataflow, and it can be launched from the button with two connected boxes.
Programs can be simple, adding or comparing two numbers, or sophisticated, with many nodes that control outputs based on inputs.
Try adding a Dataflow tile to your Workspace. Once you add the tile, you can add different types of blocks from the menu on the left side and connect them just like in the sample program below.
Blocks can be:
1. Inputs (e.g., a temperatue sensor). These are the blue-ish blocks.
2. Processing blocks (e.g., "Math" or "Logic"). These are the green-ish blocks.
3. Outputs (e.g., a light bulb). These are the orange blocks.
Sensor blocks

Sensor blocks, the first choice on the Dataflow menu, allow you to put a stream of data into your program. Choose a sensor from the top dropdown menu. You will see a variety of quantities you can measure.

If you don't have a real, physical sensor handy, you can pick a set of demo data from the second dropdown menu. The selection menu will let you pick your physical EMG sensors for this class when the time is right, but for now you can use any sensor type you want and set the data to a demo set.

When you pick a sensor type and a specific (real or demo) sensor, you will immediately see a stream of readings and units in the readout box. If you want to see a little history of values, tap the graph icon. The time spacing on this graph is controlled by the Sampling Rate at the top of the Dataflow tile.
Input blocks, like the Sensor block, have only one output dot which you connect to other blocks in the program. All are shades of blue.
Math and Logic Blocks
Once you have data in your program, you will want to change it to do what you need. Green blocks are processing blocks that take one or more inputs on the left and have a single output on the right.

Here are shown Math and Logic blocks. The dropdown allows you to pick the algebraic or comparison operation you desire to perform on the two input data streams. The equivalent written expression is shown in the output box.

As soon as two data streams are connected to the input dots, the block will immediately perform it's set operation and send the result to the output dot. If you want to see a history of calculated values, tap the graph icon.
O﻿utput Blocks

P﻿rograms that manipulate data output a series of numbers. Those numbers can be a result on their own, or they can be used to control devices. Dataflow has both demo outputs and the ability to hook up to a physical output if you have one handy.

S﻿elect a type of output device, either real or demo, from the dropdown menu on the block. Demo outputs will display a picture of the device and an animation of it working according to inputs. Live outputs will prompt you to select a live connected device.

D﻿emo outputs are typically controlled by binary values, 1 = on or 0 = off, and sometimes by extended values if more states are needed to control the output device. Different outputs have different rules for handling inputs that are not one of the special values such as 1 or 0.
Try to make your own Dataflow program that adds two numbers. What are the different ways that you see the result of the program?

The following Dataflow program is supposed to monitor the outside temperature and remind you to water your lawn when the temperature is above 30 degrees celsius. However, the program is not working well. Can you drag it into your workspace and fix it?
Sharing your workspace with your group

CLUE allows you to share your screen in real-time with other students in your group. To do so, you need to turn on the Share option in top right of your Workspace, and click on "Join group view" icon next to the Share switch. You can minimize My Resources (left side) to better view your groupmates' screens. If they haven't shared their screen yet, ask them to do so.
Within your group, discuss the Dataflow programs that each one of you has created.
Publishing your workspace
When you're done with today's activities, try publishing your workspace. To do so, click on "Publish Workspace" at the top of your workspace.
When you publish, your workspace will appear under the pink "Extension" tab above. Student work will go under the Class Models and Data tab. Teacher work will go under the Custom Lessons tab.
Check if any of your classmates has published their workspace yet.
Reflection
At the end of each lesson, you will be asked to post a brief reflection. Click on the "Reflection" tab to learn more.
Throughout the neural engineering unit, you will keep a learning journal called a Learning Journal.
At the end of each lesson, you will be asked to add a journal entry to track your learning throughout the unit.
To start your journal, click on "My Work" >> "Learning Journals"
Click on "My First Learning Log" and click "Edit" in the top right of the pane.
Then, come back to this tab, drag the template below into your workspace, and answer the following questions.
My First Journal Entry
Today's date:
Today's topic:
What do you like about CLUE and Dataflow?
What can be improved?
What kind of questions do you have?

problems.title: Lesson 1.1 - What is a bionic arm?

text: Overview:
In this lesson, you will be introduced to emerging technology that helps people with neurological conditions or missing limbs.
Learning Objectives:
This activity is intended to help you come up with questions about how body systems interact with one another and with technology. We will explore these questions throughout the unit.
To start off, please drag the following tile into your workspace and answer these questions:
1) What do you know about bionic arms? (e.g., what do they look like, why people might use them, in what ways are they connected to the person’s body, how do they work)
2) If you were tasked to design a bionic arm, what do you think the people who use them would like in terms of appearance and function?
Meet Tilly

Tilly is a real-life bionic teen. At only 15 months old, Tilly had both her hands amputated at the wrist because of a very rare infection. For years she used basic silicon arms, but in 2018 she became the first child in the UK to have bionic arms. These high-tech, 3D printed arms give Tilly a much fuller range of movement. In class, you will watch a video about Tilly, who is now a model, public speaker and make-up vlogger. In the video, Tilly showcases her colorful arm cases, before applying a full face of make-up - and trying out a new edgy look.
This video received over 2M views on YouTube! You can read more about Tilly here
While watching the video, think about the following questions: (drag these questions into your workspace so you are ready to answer them after watching the video):
- How does the bionic lower arm appear to be physically attached to Tilly’s upper arm?
- How does Tilly control her bionic arm?
How does Tilly control her bionic arms?

Create a model on paper or a whiteboard or in a drawing tile that explains how Tilly's bionic arms work. If you worked on paper or a whiteboard, take a picture of your model and upload it to your workspace in an image tile.
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning journal (see Reflection tab).
As you recall, throughout the neural engineering unit, you will keep a learning journal.
To access your journal, click on "My Work" >> "Learning Journals"
Click on "My First Learning Log" and click "Edit" .
Then, come back to this tab, drag the template below into your workspace, and answer the following questions.
Lesson 1.1 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. Based on the video and the class discussion, please describe your current understanding of how bionic arms work.
4. What questions would you like to ask Tilly (the teen with the bionic arms from the video)?

In this lesson, you will learn about electrical signals in the human body, measure your reaction time, and develop a model to explain how body systems interact during limb movement. This will help you understand how bionic arms work (like the ones used by Tilly).
Learning Objective
By the end of this activity, you will be able to explain what body systems are involved in limb movement and how they interact with one another.
Do Now
Working with your classmates, explore the behavior of energy sticks. You may try the following:
1) Have one person touch both ends of the energy sticks.
2) Have two people touch the energy stick while holding hands.
3) Get a group of students to hold hands in a circle. Put the energy stick between two of the students. Does it turn on?
4) Give one pair of students something to hold between them (e.g., a metal key or a pencil). Do these objects conduct or insulate?
In your workspace, answer the following question: How can energy sticks help us understand how Tilly's bionic arms work?
Program a Light Bulb to Turn On and Off
We can use a computer program to turn lights on and off in the same way you just did with the energy sticks.
Here is a very simple program that turns a light bulb on and off based on a timer:

Drag this program to your workspace and modify it in the following way: instead of a timer, use a generator to control the light bulb. To do so, delete the timer and add a generator. Select the "Square" option and add some logic to make the light bulb only turn on when the generated signal is over 0.5.
Measure your reaction time
How long does it take you to react to signals, such as a changing street crossing sign or catching a ball?

As explained in the video that you watched in class, you will work with a partner to measure your reaction time, comparing your dominant and non-dominant hand. Do you expect to observe a difference in reaction time between your two hands?
To find out, follow these steps:
1. Decide who is the Dropper and who is the Catcher.

2. The catcher should extend their dominant hand (the hand used for writing) with the index finger and thumb about 1 cm apart. The dropper should hold the ruler at the top such that catcher has their thumb and index fingers on either side of the zero cm mark.
3. When the catcher says they are ready. the dropper should count up, in their head, to a number between 3 and 5 (use a different number each time). When the number is reached, they drop the ruler.
4. Catcher catches the ruler as fast as they can. Ignore any times the ruler falls on the ground.
5. Enter the ruler cm value closest to Catcher’s pinch point in the table below (you should first drag the table to your worksheet).
6. Repeat steps 2-5 five times.
7. Repeat the process with the catcher's non-dominant hand.
Results Table
Drag these tables into your Workspace and use them to record and calculate your results.
Use the table below to convert drop distance (in cm) to time (in milliseconds, which is thousands of a second):
Discuss the following questions with your partner and enter your answers in your workspace:
1. Why were you asked to measure your reaction time five times with each hand?
2. What factors affect our reaction time?
Extension activity
With your partner, take a video of one of you catching an object and play it in slow motion.
On iPhone: Go into the camera and click “Slo-mo” to take slow motion video
On Android: Go into the camera, click “video” and then select “slow motion” option.
What did you observe when watching the slow motion videos? Please document your observation in your worksheet.
Making models

With a group of 2-3 other students, make a list of all body systems that affect reaction time. With these body systems in mind, make an illustrated (drawing) and annotated (text) model of the sequence of events occurring during the time at which the ruler was falling. You can use a drawing tile to make your model within your workspace or draw the model on paper/whiteboard and then upload a picture to your workspace. Be prepared to share your thinking during a whole class discussion.
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning journal (see Reflection tab).
Please load your Learning Journal ("My Work" >> "Learning Journal").
Then, come back to this tab, drag the template below into your workspace, and answer the following questions.
Lesson 1.2 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. How do body systems and their interaction help us respond quickly to stimuli?
4. How would your reaction time be affected if you used bionic arms like Tilly? Why?

problems.title: Lesson 1.3 - How does nerve injury affect movement?

text: Today you will learn about the nervous system and investigate different neurological conditions that could affect movement.
Learning Objectives
By the end of this activity, you should be able to describe how different neurological conditions (e.g., spinal cord injury) impact movement.
Do Now
What do you already know about how the nervous system controls movement? Add a text tile in your workspace and answer this question.
Anatomy of the nervous system

The nervous system guides almost everything you do. It controls complex functions, such as movement, thought, and memory, as well as vital functions, such as breathing. The nervous system is made of billions of specialized cells called neurons. Neurons use electrical signals to communicate with one another. Different kinds of neurons send different signals. Motor neurons make your muscles move, whereas sensory neurons pick up information from the environment (sight, sound, touch etc.) and send signals to your brain.
The nervous system has two main parts
Central nervous system: Consists of the brain and spinal cord.
Peripheral nervous system: Consists of nerves that branch out from the brain and spinal cord all over your body.

Annotate the parts of the nervous system in the following image by adding a text tile to your workspace and indicating what part of the nervous system is marked by each number. Then, think about how each part of the nervous system might be involved in controlling limb movement. Note: you can also drag images into drawing tiles so you can write on top of them.
How does nerve injury affect movement?

In the next activity, you will investigate how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement. Your team may choose or be assigned to explore one of the following injuries:

• Brain Injury
  • Spinal Cord Injury
  • Peripheral Nerve Injury
In your workspace, summarize in your own words how the injury that you read about could impact limb movement.
Reflection
Please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning Journal (see Reflection tab).
Modeling movement

We can use a simple computer program to model how the brain controls limb movement. In the following program, the limb is represented by a robotic grabber that can open or close. Drag this program into your workspace and try to get the grabber to close.
Hint: You will need to add a "brain" to the program and connect it to the grabber.
Please load your Learning journal ("My Work" >> "Learning Journals").
Then, come back to this tab, drag the template below into your workspace, and answer the following questions.
Lesson 1.3 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. How would your daily life be affected by the injury that your group has explored?
4. Of the three injury types that had been discussed (brain, spinal cord, peripheral nerve), which injury type best characterizes Tilly’s condition?
In this lesson, you will use a technique called Electromyography (EMG) to measure your muscle electrical activity.
Learning Objectives
By the end of today's lesson, you will be able to acquire and make sense of muscle electrical activity (EMG) data.

tiles.title: Flexing muscles to make a EMG trace [Credit: Backyard Brains]

text: D﻿o Now
Drag and drop the following tile into your workspace and answer the following question:
What do you already know about how muscles contract?
Visualize and Record Muscle Activity

Let’s measure your muscle activity! In order to make muscle activity usable as data to drive Bionics, we need to be able to measure it. For this, we will use EMG sensors, which measure the electrical activity that occurs when you contract or expand your muscles.
For this activity you will need the following materials:

Muscle SpikerShield (yellow board) coupled with an Arduino board (blue). The Muscle SpikerShield allows you to record your muscle's electrical activity (known as Electromyography or EMG). The yellow board has a small switch that reads 'EMG' on one side and 'Control' on the other. The switch should be on the 'EMG' position.
Orange Muscle Electrode Cable with 3 alligator clips (two reds, one black).

tiles.title: USB Cable connects Arduino to Computer

text: A USB data cable that connects the Arduino board to a computer.
Sticker electrodes - used to pick up electrical signals from your muscles.
A computer desktop with the Backyard Brains Spike Recorder app.
One hand grip (optional)
Proceedure
1. Connect the Arduino board to your computer using the blue USB cable.

2. Decide who is going to be the study participant (you can take turns). Place two electrode stickers on the participant’s forearm close to each other and another one on the participant’s elbow (this is the reference electrode)
3. Connect the orange muscle electrode cable (the one with the three alligators) to the Muscle SpikerShield orange connector:
4. Connect the two red alligators to the electrodes on your arm. The black cable should be connected to the reference electrode:

5. Open the Backyard Brains Spike Recorder App on your computer. Click on the gear icon at the top left corner of the screen. Click on the 'Connect' button just below 'Select Port' (you may need to make the app window larger to view this option).

The signals that you see on the screen reflect your muscle electrical activity. Change the time scale of your signal to ~1 second by scrolling up/down. You can also use the “+” and “-­” buttons you to change the vertical scale.
Hold the hand grip and squeeze it (or just make a fist) - how does the display change?"
EMG Experiment

Now it is time to explore your EMG muscle activity. With your group, select 3 of the following research questions and answer them in your workspace. Make sure to include screenshots from the Spike Recorder App as evidence and describe what is shown in each image. (Screenshots can be copied and pasted into image or drawing tiles in your workspace.)

• How does muscle activity vary between one’s dominant vs. non-dominant hand?
  • How does muscle activity vary between different muscles (e.g., forearm vs. forehead muscles)?
  • How does muscle activity vary between agonist and antagonist muscles?
  • What happens when we activate our hand muscles for an extended period of time using a hand gripper?
  • Can you predict who’s going to win an arm-wrestling contest based on the contestants’ muscle activity?
Please document your observations in your Workspace.
Reflection
Please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning Journal (see Reflection tab).
Please load your Learning Journal ("My Work" >> "Learning Journal").
Then, come back to this tab, drag the template below into your workspace, and answer the following questions.
Lesson 1.4 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. What connections do you see between today's activity and Tilly's bionic arms?
4. What questions do you have about EMG?

problems.title: Lesson 1.5 - How to control a robotic gripper

text: Today we will explore how Electromyography (EMG) signals can be used to control a robotic gripper.
Learning Objectives
By the end of this activity, you will be able to model the performance of a bionic arm.

tiles.title: Sketch of muscle control of a robot gripper

text: Think about the muscle EMG signals that we measured in the previous lesson. How would you use these signals to make a robotic gripper open or close?
Let's learn how to control a robotic gripper with your muscle activity!
Make sure that you have all the materials shown in this picture:

tiles.title: Arduino kit components to get EMG signals into Dataflow

text: Step 1: Create a program that controls the gripper
Setting up:
1. Connect the blue cable to the Arduino board and then connect the other end of the blue cable to your computer’s USB port:

2. Connect the gripper to the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board). Note that there is a cable coming out of the gripper with three wires (yellow, red, and black). Look closely at the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board on top of the Arduino). Next to the gray-ish box, there are three pins labeled “Y” (for yellow), “R” (red), and “B” (black). Gently connect the gripper to the Muscle SpikerShield as shown here:
3. Look closely at the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board) and find the EMG <> Control switch. Make sure that the switch in on "Control"
4. Create a Dataflow tile in your workspace and add a "Live Output" block. Select "Grabber" from the dropdown menu.

5. Click on the "flashlight" button in the top-right corner of the Dataflow tile in order to connect to the gripper. The browser will open a popup that says the site would like to connect to a Serial Port.
There should only be one choice. Click on it and then hit the connect button.

tiles.title: Browser connection dialog to the Arduino

text: 6. To make the gripper open and close, you will need to add an input block (for example, a timer or a generator) and connect it to the output block.
7. Power up the gripper by connecting a 9V battery to the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board). The gripper should close, wait, and open.
8. Experiment with different input types (for example, if you used a timer, switch it to a generator).
9. When you're done, delete the Dataflow tile and unplug the battery.
Explanation of the above code blocks (not for students):

In this activity, there is only one muscle (EMG) sensor. Students can choose one of the Demo inputs or a connected Arduino. When the student choses 'BB EMG’ from the Sensor block menu then they will get a browser dialog allowing them to select the hardware for real-time data input.
Output: Students can either choose ‘Demo Output’ blocks for a simulated output device (an animated gripper that opens and closes) or the Live Output block to control an external device.
The signal is interpreted as a percentage between 0 and 1 mapped to how far the gripper is closed. Note that students must normalize the signal inputs so that
The logic block might need to detect if the EMG crosses the threshold with a rising or falling edge. The polarity of the cross may inform whether the gripper opens or closes.
Step 2: Create a program that reads EMG data
1. Stick two EMG surface electrodes on your forearm and one on your elbow.
2. Find the orange cord that ends in two red and one black alligator clips.
3. Connect the black alligator clip to the electrode on your elbow and the red alligator clips to the electrodes on your forearm.
4. Plug the end of the orange wire into the orange connection box on the Muscle SpikerShield.

tiles.title: diagram showing arm electrodes and Arduino

text: 5. Create a new Dataflow tile and add a sensor block:
- In the "Select a sensor type" drop-down menu, select EMG
- In the "Select a sensor" drop-down menu, select "connect for live EMG"
6. Click on the button with the flashlight, where it says "click to finish connection"
- The browser may open a popup that says the site would like to connect to a Serial Port.
- There should only be one choice. Click on it and then hit the connect button.
7. Set the sampling rate to 100ms
8. Click on the graph icon in the EMG sensor block to visualize the incoming data. Do you see a change in the reading when you contract your arm muscles?
Step 3: Add a simulated output
To make sure that the program reads your EMG data correctly, add a demo output. For example, try to make a program that turns on a virtual light bulb when the EMG reading is above a certain value.
Tip: you will need to use Logic and Number blocks.
Next, instead of a light bulb choose a grabber demo. Can you make the simulated grabber open and close when you contract your arm muscles?
Step 4: Control a real-life gripper with your muscles
Finally, replace the Demo Output block with a Live Output Block. In the drop-down menu, choose "Grabber."
Power up the gripper by connecting a 9V battery to the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board).
Can you make the gripper open and close by contracting your arm muscles?
Congratulations! You just created a model of bionic arm!
Try experimenting with:
1. The sensitivity of the device (can be changed by pressing the gray button on the Muscle SpikerShield).
2. The locations of the EMG electrodes. Can you control the gripper more effectively with different muscles?
3. Grasping objects of different sizes/weights.
Extra challenge

Can you make the gripper close in proportion to the amplitude of the EMG signal? In other words, can you make the gripper close just slightly with a minor muscle contraction and fully close with a major muscle contraction?

Tip: The Live Grabber block expects a number between 0 and 1 that tells it how much to close. You will need to replace the Logic block with a Math block to convert the EMG signal to a number between 0 and 1.
** Remember to disconnect the 9V battery at the end of class **
Evaluate the design of the gripper
Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of the EMG-controlled gripper with your group and summarize the conversation in your workspace.
How would you improve the design of the gripper? Try to sketch some ideas on paper and upload a picture to your workspace.
Reflection
Please record your current thinking and learning in your KWL journal (see Reflection tab).
Please load your Learning journal ("My Work" >> "Learning Journal").
Then, come back to this tab, drag the template below into your workspace, and answer the following questions.
Lesson 1.5 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. How would you modify the design of the EMG-controlled gripper so it can help people like Tilly?

problems.title: Lesson 2.1 - How does touch impact movement?

text: In this lesson, you will learn about how sensory feedback impacts our ability to move and interact with objects.
Do Now
Discuss the following questions with a classmate and then record your answers individually in your workspace:
1) What are some challenges that you may encounter when trying to hold fragile objects (e.g., an egg) with the robotic gripper?
2) How would you improve the design of the gripper to overcome these challenges?
Does reaction time depend on tactile feedback?

As you recall, in lesson 1.2, you measured your reaction time using a ruler, comparing your dominant and non-dominant hand. Today we will conduct a similar experiment to investigate how tactile information impacts reaction time (in other words, how being able to feel the ruler with our fingertips impacts how fast we are at catching it?).
If you need a reminder on how to conduct the experiment, please watch this video.
Follow these steps:
1. Decide who is the Dropper and who is the Catcher.

2. The catcher should extend their hand with the index finger and thumb about 1 cm apart. The dropper should hold the ruler at the top such that the catcher has their thumb and index fingers on either side of the zero cm mark.
3. When the catcher says they are ready. the dropper should count up, in their head, to a number between 3 and 5 (use a different number each time). When the number is reached, they drop the ruler.
4. Catcher catches the ruler as fast as they can. Ignore any times the ruler falls on the ground.
5. Enter the ruler cm value closest to Catcher’s pinch point in the table below (you should first drag the table to your worksheet).
6. Repeat steps 2-5 five times.
7. Repeat the process while the catcher is wearing a winter glove.
Drag the following tables into your workspace and use them to record and calculate your results.
Use the table below to convert drop distance (in cm) to time (in milliseconds, which is thousands of a second):
Discuss the following question with your partner and enter your answers in your workspace:
How did wearing a glove affect your reaction time? Why?
PBS News Hour story
Answer the following question after watching the first 3 minutes of the PBS News Hour story
What stood out to you in the video? List at least 3 things in your workspace.
Design an improved gripper
Create a model on paper or a whiteboard to communicate how information about touch/pressure can be incorporated into the design of the gripper. Some things to consider:
1. How would you measure the pressure applied by the gripper on objects?
2. How would touch/pressure information impact the opening/closing of the gripper?
Make sure to label your model. When you're done, take a picture of your model and upload it to your workspace as an image tile.
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning journal (see Reflection tab).
Add the following entry to your learning journal:
Lesson 2.1 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. Based on today's lesson, describe how information about touch/pressure affects our movement.
4. How do you think Tilly (the teen with the bionic arms) would react to the improved gripper that you designed today?

problems.title: Lesson 2.2 - How do we perceive touch?

text: Today we will explore how the nervous system processes information about touch.
Do Now

Some body parts are much more sensitive to touch than others. For example, the fingertips are one of the most touch-sensitive parts of the body, whereas the elbow is one of the least touch-sensitive body parts. How can you explain these differences in touch sensitivity? Enter some ideas in your workspace.
Measuring touch sensitivity
Decide who is going to be the experimenter and who will be the test subject (you should take turns such that all team members will be a test subject once).

1. The test subject should close their eyes.
  2. The experimenter should gently press the caliper’s jaws against the skin of the test subject, and ask them if they feel one point or two points of contact (the two points need to touch the skin at the same time).
  3. Set the caliper’s jaw at a distance of 60mm and keep testing smaller and smaller distances (30mm, 15mm, 7.5mm, 3.75mm) until the subject indicates that they feel one point only.
  4. Test the forehead, back, arm, palm of the hand, leg, and feet as shown in the picture below in any order.
  5. Record the first distance that the subject felt as one point (or the last distance that was tested) in the table below.
  6. Enter the numbers from your table here [link: https://brainmapper.org/experiment/]
  7. Take a screenshot of the resulting homunculus. You can then upload your homunculus into your workspace by creating an image tile and dragging or uploading the image from your desktop into the tile.

tiles.title: Take these measurements for each student

text: Drag the table into your workspace so you can fill it out for each person you test:
Answer the following questions in your workspace:
1. What is the most/least sensitive body part?
2. Why do different parts of the body have different sensitivity to touch?
3. How consistent were your results across test subjects? What can explain individual differences in touch sensitivity?
How does the nervous system process touch?
Information about touch is processed by several components of the nervous system:

• Somatosensory cortex
  • Pressure receptors in the skin
  • Thalamus
  • Sensory nerves
  • Spinal cord

Read online about each of these components and make an illustrated and annotated model that communicates how these components are connected to each other. When you're done, take a picture of your model and upload it to your workspace as an image tile. Can you explain why some parts of the body are more sensitive to touch than others based on this model?
Modeling touch receptors in DataFlow
Next, let's design a DataFlow program that detects the level of pressure applied by the gripper and makes the gripper release an object when too much pressure is applied.

1. Drag the following program to your workspace and connect the blocks such that the gripper stays closed. This program simulates an extended muscle contraction that keeps the gripper closed for a long period of time.
2. Add a pressure sensor. To do so, click on "Sensor" and select "Surface Pressure" as a sensor type. Then, select "FSR Demo Data" in the second dropdown menu.
3. Add a logic block to check if the pressure is above 1000 (we'll assume that 1000 represents excessive pressure that can break a fragile object).
4. Next, we will need to use a new block type called "Control" (see image below). This block receives two inputs:
Input 1 (the top one) determines if the block is on or off.
Input 2 (the bottom one) determines which value is passed through.
If the control block is OFF, it simply passes input 2 through. In other words, the output would be equal to input 2.
If the control block is ON, it can do different things, such as outputting the number zero. This option is useful because when the gripper receives the number zero it opens up.
5. Finally, connect all the blocks together such that when the pressure is greater than 1000 the gripper opens up to release the object.
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning journal (see Reflection tab).
Lesson 2.2 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. Based on today's lesson, describe what determines the touch sensitivty of different body parts.
4. How sensitive to touch do you think Tilly's bionic arms need to be in order for her to use them effectively?

In the last two lessons we explored the significant role of the nervous system in processing sensory information, as well as the impact of refined sensory information on movement. In this activity we will explore how a simple model of a bionic arm can be designed so that pressure can be sensed. In this activity, you will be presented with the following challenge:
How can robotic grippers can sense objects?
Do Now

Think back to what you have learned in lesson 2.1 (how does touch impact movement?) and lesson 2.2 (how do we perceive touch?). Answer the following question in your workspace: How would change the design of the gripper to make it "feel" objects?
Working with pressure sensors
Today we will work with pressure sensors to make the gripper "feel" objects. To do so, you will need to attach sensing "mittens" to your gripper:
Step 1: Flip the gripper over so the black battery is facing up and lay the mittens in front of the gripper so the arcs of the mittens are facing each other:
Step 2: Slide the mitten under the gripper like so, and gently push on the orange arm into the mitten. It should be a snug fit. Repeat with the other mitten.

Step 3: If the mittens do not fit the arm of the gripper snug, then repeat step two, but pull the mitten up while holding the gripper arm steady. The mitten should tighten around the arm of the gripper.

Step 4: After the mittens are securely attached to the gripper arm, you will need to attach the touch sensor (if the sensor is already attached to one of the mittens, skip steps #4-5). Guide the pressure sensor through the small slit of one of the mittens (doesn't matter which one):

Step 5: Take a small piece of double sided tape and attach the sensor to the arc of the mitten.Push the back of the pressure sensor into the double-sided tape. Make sure that the striped side of the sensor is facing OUT (note: The pressure sensor will not work if the wrong side is taped):

The next step is to connect the pressure sensor to the Muscle Spiker Shield (orange board). You will notice that there are three wires coming out of the sensor: red, black, and blue. Plug these wires to the following sockets:

tiles.title: Connecting the sensor to the muscle spiker shield (orange board)

text: Next, you will need to connect the Arduino board to your computer using the blue USB cable, open a DataFlow tile and click on the lightning bolt connection button to pair your device. Add a sensor to your DataFlow program and choose "Surface Pressure" from the first drop-down menu and "connect for live fsr" from the second drop-down menu. Click on the graph icon to visualize the data that is received from the sensor and change the sampling rate to 100ms.
Try pressing the sensor with your fingers. Do you see any changes in your graph? If not, make sure you properly followed all the previous steps.
Control the gripper with your muscles
Follow the same steps from lesson 1.5 to control the gripper with your muscles (go back to lesson 1.5 if you need additional information):
1. Connect the gripper to the Muscle SpikerShield.
2. Stick two EMG surface electrodes on your forearm and one on your elbow.
3. Connect the black alligator clip to the electrode on your elbow and the red alligator clips to the electrodes on your forearm.
4. Plug the end of the orange wire into the orange connection box on the Muscle SpikerShield.
5. Create a new DataFlow tile and add a sensor block:
- In the "Select a sensor type" drop-down menu, select EMG
- In the "Select a sensor" drop-down menu, select "connect for live EMG"
6. Add a Live Output Block. In the drop-down menu, choose "Grabber."
7. Add logic and number blocks and connect all the blocks (just like you did in lesson 1.5).
8. Power up the gripper by connecting a 9V battery to the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board).
Can you make the gripper open and close by contracting your arm muscles? If not, check your work and make sure you followed all the previous steps correctly.
Your challenge, should you choose to accept it...

Your goal in this final activity is to program the gripper to hold an egg without cracking it. Your DataFlow program should do two main things: (1) when a muscle is contracted, the signal is detected and triggers the gripper to close. (2) When the pressure applied on an object becomes too strong, the pressure sensor tells the gripper to keep its current position. This is meant to prevent the gripper from closing too strongly on the egg and cracking it.
Hint: You will need to use a "control" block (see lesson 2.2).
Before you test your program with a real egg, try pressing the sensor with your fingers and contracting your muscles at the same time. Does your gripper move? Why or why not?
Evaluate the design of the touch-sensitive gripper
With your team, discuss the strengths and weaknesses of the touch-sensitive gripper. Drag the following table to your workspace and fill it in:
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your learning journal (see Reflection tab).
Add the following entry to your learning journal:
Lesson 2.3 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. Based on your analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of the touch-sensitive gripper, what modification would you make to improve the gripper's functionality?
4. Pressure receptors are just one type of sensor. What sensors do you think would be most useful for Tilly (the girl with the bionic arms)?

problems.title: Lesson 2.4 - Can you design a human-machine interface?

text: In this lesson, you will have the opportunity to use what you have learned throughout the unit to design a technological solution for one of several end users.
Do Now
Think about a person (other than Tilly) who could benefit from the touch-sensitive gripper that you used in the previous lesson. Describe this person and their needs in your workspace.
Select a case study
The cases below describe people who have sensory or motor conditions that impact their life quality. Review these cases and decide who you would like to help today.
Mrs. Marcus

Maria Marcus is 84 years old. When she was younger she worked as a pharmacist. This required routine use of her hands as she measured and mixed medicines that were able to restore the health of community members. Mrs. Marcus is enjoying her retirement, with ample time to bake for her nine grandchildren and maintain her flower garden with her husband of 60 years.

Recently Mrs. Marcus is unsettled to find that arthritis in her hands has resulted in something her primary care physician, Dr. Romero, has diagnosed as hypoesthesia. Hypoesthesia is reduced or complete loss of sensation. In Mrs. Marcus’s case, Dr. Romero believes that inflammation of joints in Mrs. Marcus’s hands are pressing against the surrounding nerves, resulting in numbness. This is unsafe, especially given Mrs. Marcus is unable to sense temperature and touch in her fingers when she bakes.
Tilly

Tilly Lockey lost her hands at fifteen months of age due to a bacterial infection. After eleven years without hands, Tilley received a pair of bionic hands. Now sixteen years old, she is now able to open doors and cupboards without the help of her parents or sister. Tilly feels empowered by this new-found independence. She also likes to design the plastic outer cases of her bionic arms, which has become an important part of expressing who she is.

As you noticed in the video, Tilly is happy to be able to more easily apply makeup with her bionic hands. However, Tilly finds it difficult to do some of the eye makeup techniques she found on Instagram. Tilly would like to be able to apply false lashes on her own, but her current bionic hands are unable to pick up and hold delicate objects.

tiles.title: Tilly applies makeup with bionic hands

text: Mr. Johnson

Isaiah Johnson is 72 years old. When he was younger he worked as a social worker at the local Veterans Administration Medical Center. Mr. Johnson found it very rewarding to help people navigate challenges. Now that he is retired, Mr. Johnson has been spending more time volunteering with his wife Janelle at the community food garden they had initiated just before the birth of their second child.

Shortly after he was drafted to serve in the Vietnam War, at nineteen years of age, Mr. Johnson lost his sense of sight during an explosion in which shrapnel struck his face. Mr. Johnson’s guide dog, a golden labrador named Rex, helps Mr. Johnson safely stroll across the city’s sidewalks and streets. Recently Mrs. Johnson had hip surgery, and Mr. Johnson came to realize he is not as independent as he thought. As Mrs. Johnson recuperated on a rented electric hospital bed in the living room, Mr. Johnson prepared stove top and microwave meals. As he began to prepare Mrs. Johnson’s favorite pot roast, he realized that it would be unsafe to use the oven because he would not sense where the hot cast iron skillet was located. This frustrated Mr. Johnson, who has taken pride in his ability to live life fully despite eye damage.

tiles.title: Mr. Johnson and his seeing eye dog

text: Define the challenge
Please drag the following questions to your workspace and answer them:
What are the challenges experienced by the person that you chose?
Why is it important to address these challenges?
How can you apply what you have learned throughout the unit to help this individual?
Idea generation

Using your knowledge of body systems and technology, propose a device that can help the person described in the case. Please sketch your proposed device on a whiteboard/chart paper, with annotations. Take a picture when you're done and upload it to your workspace.
As you design your device, ask yourself:
Will [person’s name] find the device safe?
Will [person’s name] find the device easy to use?
Will [person’s name] find the device comfortable?
Will [person’s name] find the device useful?
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your learning journal (see Reflection tab).
Add the following entry to your learning journal:
Lesson 2.4 Journal Entry
1. Today's date:
2. Today's topic:
3. Imagine yourself meeting the person who was described in your case. How do you think the person would react to the device that you designed?
